JUDGES: Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä;Sverre Erik Jebens;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , “ G ” , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON , ORG .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . NORP In DATE , when the applicant was CARDINAL , he had sexual intercourse with a DATE girl ( “ the complainant ” ) at his home , using a condom .

CARDINAL . DATE friends of the complainant became concerned when she admitted to them that she had had sexual intercourse with the applicant . They took her to a family planning clinic . The clinic called the police . In a video - recorded interview the complainant gave the following account of what had occurred . After a casual meeting she spoke to the applicant on a couple of occasions by mobile telephone and they arranged to meet again . Because it was raining they went to the applicant 's home . They went into his bedroom “ to talk ” . The door was closed , and possibly locked . The applicant quizzed her about her school . Suddenly he took down her trousers and flung them across the room . She understood what was about to happen and , alarmed , made clear her objections . Despite these , the applicant proceeded to have vaginal intercourse with her . They remained TIME in the room , then parted . They had no further contact .

CARDINAL . On the basis of this evidence , the applicant was charged with rape of a child under CARDINAL , contrary to section CARDINAL of LAW DATE ( “ theCARDINAL Act ” : see below ) . He was advised that he had no defence to the charge .
CARDINAL . On DATE he pleaded guilty on the following basis , as recorded in writing :
“ i ) The complainant willingly agreed to have sexual intercourse with the defendant .
ii ) At the time the defendant believed that the complainant was DATE . She told him so on an earlier occasion .

iii ) The defendant nonetheless pleads guilty to the ... offence having been advised that , by reason of the fact that the complainant was DATE at the relevant time , the offence is committed irrespective of :
a ) consent
b ) reasonable belief in consent
c ) a reasonable belief as to age . ”

CARDINAL . NORP The prosecution were not , initially , prepared to accept this basis of plea and a “ GPE ” hearing was fixed for CARDINAL and DATE in order to determine the correct factual basis for the purpose of sentence . The complainant was , however , terrified of attending court and so , with the support of her mother , decided that she was content with the basis of plea . On DATE , however , the prosecution informed the applicant 's solicitors that they had decided to accept the basis of plea advanced because the complainant had accepted that she had told the applicant that she was CARDINAL and she was reluctant to attend court to give evidence . The prosecution declined to consider , as they were invited to do by those representing the applicant , whether it was in the public interest to proceed with the prosecution .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was sentenced to a DATE detention and training order . He was detained for DATE before being granted bail on being given permission to appeal against sentence .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed to ORG against conviction and sentence on the grounds inter alia that ( CARDINAL ) the conviction violated his right to a fair trial and the presumption of innocence under LAW , because the offence was one of strict liability , and ( CARDINAL ) it violated his right to respect for private life under LAW because it was disproportionate to charge him with rape under LAW when he could have been charged with a less serious offence under LAW , which deals with sex offences committed by persons DATE ( see below ) . On DATE ORG ( Lord PERSON , PERSON , PERSON ) dismissed the appeal against conviction but allowed the appeal against sentence , substituting a conditional discharge ( see G v R [ DATE ] EWCA Crim CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG held that the offence under section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act was committed by a person having vaginal , anal or oral sexual intercourse with a victim under CARDINAL , whether or not the victim consented and regardless of whether the defendant reasonably believed that the child was CARDINAL or over . It found that no issue arose under LAW , which did not prevent a ORG from creating offences of strict liability . ORG accepted that prosecution of a minor for an offence under section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act in respect of “ consensual ” sexual intercourse might in certain cases give rise to a violation of LAW . To prevent this , it would be possible for the trial judge to substitute a charge LAW ( see below ) once the full facts had emerged . Moreover , the judge 's sentencing powers in relation to the conviction of a child of an offence under LAW ranged from absolute discharge to detention for life . If it transpired that the facts of the offence were less serious than those that originally justified the charge , the judge should normally , by an appropriate sentence , be able to ensure that there was no unjustified interference with the defendant 's LAW . On the facts of the applicant 's case , the judge did not infringe LAW by proceeding to sentence the applicant under LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG granted leave to appeal . On DATE , their Lordships ( Lords Hoffmann , Hope of ORG and ORG and ORG ) dismissed the appeal ( see G v R [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . NORP ORG unanimously held that LAW and CARDINAL guaranteed fair procedure and the presumption of innocence but did not place any obligation on GPE as regards the substantive contents of domestic law , including the mental or other elements of offences under domestic criminal law .

CARDINAL . They also rejected the applicant 's complaint under LAW by a majority of CARDINAL to CARDINAL ( Lords PERSON and PERSON and ORG in the majority , ORG and ORG dissenting ) . The majority held that , even if the applicant 's LAW were engaged , his prosecution , conviction and sentence were proportionate in the pursuit of the legitimate aims of the protection of health and morals and of the rights and freedoms of others .
CARDINAL . Baroness PERSON observed as follows :

“ CARDINAL . LAW has CARDINAL main features . First , it singles out penetration by the male penis as one of the most serious sorts of sexual behaviour towards a child DATE ; secondly , it applies to such penetration of a child under CARDINAL of either sex ; and thirdly it calls this ' rape ' . ... This is because the law regards the attitude of the victim of this behaviour as irrelevant to the commission of the offence ( although it may , of course , be relevant to the appropriate sentence ) . Even if a child is fully capable of understanding and freely agreeing to such sexual activity , which may often be doubted , especially with a child under CARDINAL , the law says that it makes no difference . He or she is legally disabled from consenting .

CARDINAL . ... It is important to stress that the object is not only to protect such children from predatory adult paedophiles but also to protect them from premature sexual activity of all kinds . They are protected in CARDINAL ways : first , by the fact that it is irrelevant whether or not they want or appear to want it ; and secondly , by the fact that in the case of children DATE it is irrelevant whether or not the possessor of the penis in question knows the age of the child he is penetrating .

CARDINAL . ... There was a great deal of anxiety in ORG about criminalising precocious sexual activity between children . The offences covered by LAW in combination with section CARDINAL cover any sort of sexual touching however mild and however truly consensual . As sexual touching is usually a mutual activity , both the children involved might in theory be prosecuted . Indeed , section CARDINAL expressly contemplates that the person penetrated may be the offender . Obviously , therefore , there will be wide variations in the blameworthiness of the behaviour caught by sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL . Both prosecutors and sentencers will have to make careful judgments about who should be prosecuted and what punishment , if any , is appropriate . In many cases , there will be no reason to take any official action at all . In others , protective action by the children 's services , whether in respect of the perpetrator or the victim or both , may be more appropriate . But the message of sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL is that any sort of sexual activity with a child under DATE is an offence , unless in the case of a child who has reached CARDINAL the perpetrator reasonably believed that the child was aged CARDINAL or over . There are many good policy reasons for the law to convey that message , not only to adults but also to the children themselves .
DATE .

CARDINAL ... The concept of private life ' covers the physical and moral integrity of the person , including his or her sexual life ' ( X and Y v The GPE , para . CARDINAL ) . This does not mean that every sexual relationship , however brief or unsymmetrical , is worthy of respect , nor is every sexual act which a person wishes to perform . It does mean that the physical and moral integrity of the complainant , vulnerable by reason of her age if nothing else , was worthy of respect . The state would have been open to criticism if it did not provide her with adequate protection . This it attempts to do by a clear rule that children DATE are incapable of giving any sort of consent to sexual activity and treating penile penetration as a most serious form of such activity . This does not in my view amount to a lack of respect for the private life of the penetrating male . ”
CARDINAL . In his dissenting judgment , Lord Hope ( with whom Lord PERSON agreed ) observed as follows :

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) guarantees to everyone the right to respect for his private life , and a teenager has as much to respect for his private life as any other individual . It is unlawful for a prosecutor to act in a way which is inconsistent with a Convention right . So I can not accept Lord PERSON 's proposition that the Convention rights have nothing to do with prosecutorial policy . How an offence is described and the range of sentences that apply to it are matters for the contracting state . But where choices are left to the prosecutor they must be exercised compatibly with the Convention rights . ...

CARDINAL . ... The offences which LAW has created are expressed in very broad terms . They recognise that the circumstances in which mutual sexual activity may take place between children of the same or the opposite sex , and the acts that they may perform on one another as fashions change , will inevitably vary greatly for case to case . But there is great force in the point that PERSON made in R v PERSON ; R v LOC [ DATE ] CARDINAL SCR CARDINAL about the need for children to be protected . Their need to be protected against themselves is as obvious as is their need to be protected from each other . There is much to be said for the view that where acts are perpetrated on children DATE by children of a similar age intervention of some kind is necessary for the protection of their physical and moral health . My noble and learned friend PERSON of GPE offers a unique insight into these issues , and I agree with all she says about the dangers of under age sexual activity . The fact that there was consent is to this extent simply irrelevant . ...

CARDINAL . The Children 's Hearing system provided for in LAW ( Scotland ) Act DATE is not available in GPE and GPE . So sexual activity between children of the kind described in this case can not be dealt with outside the criminal law . I am not suggesting that it should be decriminalised here . That would be to condone it which , as PERSON observations about the risks to vulnerable young people so clearly indicate , would not be acceptable . But this still begs the question whether sexual crimes committed by children should be dealt with in the same way as sexual crimes committed by adults . There are grounds for thinking that the sanctions that can be imposed under LAW for mutual sexual activity by a person under CARDINAL with a child under CARDINAL provide all that is needed by way of punishment that is proportionate to the offence . The message that this is an offence can be conveyed to children as well as adults very effectively by the use of these sanctions , as anyone who has exercised the responsibility of sentencing children in cases of that kind knows .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL , the rape of a child under CARDINAL , on the other hand is designed for a different and much more serious situation . The offence is one which only a male person can commit . It may be committed by a male person of any age , and he is liable on conviction to life imprisonment . The description of the offence as rape , and all the consequences that go with that description , are entirely appropriate where the act has been committed upon a child under CARDINAL by a person over DATE . It may also be appropriate where the person who committed it was under that age . But the lower the age , the less appropriate it will be . The question in such a case , given the choice that is available , must be whether in all the circumstances to proceed under LAW would be proportionate . ORG said that the judge should have taken the view , having regard to the basis of the plea , that the offence in this case fell properly within the ambit of LAW rather than section CARDINAL : para CARDINAL . I agree , but I would go further . I think that it must follow that , as the offence fell properly within the ambit of section CARDINAL , the appellant 's conviction of rape under section CARDINAL was disproportionate . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act provides :
“ Rape of a child under CARDINAL
( CARDINAL ) A person commits an offence if-
( a ) he intentionally penetrates the vagina , anus or mouth of another person with his penis , and
( b ) the other person is DATE .
( CARDINAL ) A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable , on conviction on indictment , to imprisonment for life . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides :
“ Child sex offences committed by children or young persons
( CARDINAL ) A person DATE commits an offence if he does anything which would be an offence under any of sections CARDINAL [ sexual activity with a child ] if he were aged DATE .
( CARDINAL ) A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable –
( a ) on summary conviction , to imprisonment for a term not exceeding DATE or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum or both ;
( b ) on conviction on indictment , to imprisonment for a term not DATE . ”

CARDINAL . The judge 's sentencing powers in relation to the conviction of a child under LAW range from absolute discharge to detention for life . Conviction under LAW is subject to a maximum sentence of DATE detention .
CARDINAL . In R v PERSON and other appeals [ DATE ] PERSON ORG gave guidance as to sentencing in respect of the offence created by section CARDINAL , as follows :

“ CARDINAL . Against that background , we turn to the offence of rape of a child under CARDINAL , contrary to section CARDINAL of the LAW . We say , at once , that no precise guidance can be given . The appropriate sentence is likely to lie within a very wide bracket , depending on all the circumstances of the particular offence . There will be very few cases in which immediate custody is not called for , even in relation to a young offender because the purpose of the legislation is to protect children DATE from themselves , as well as from others minded to prey upon them . ...

CARDINAL . Although absence of consent is not an ingredient of the offence , presence of consent is , in our judgment , material in relation to sentence , particularly in relation to young defendants . The age of the defendant , of itself and when compared with the age of the victim , is also an important factor . A very short period of custody is likely to suffice for a teenager where the other party consents . In exceptional cases ... a noncustodial sentence may be appropriate for a young defendant . If the offender is much older than the victim a substantial term of imprisonment will usually be called for . ”
CARDINAL . In relation to LAW , legal guidance contained in the LAW for ORG Prosecutors provides that , insofar as child defendants ( under DATE ) are concerned :

“ [ P]rosecutors may exercise more discretion where the defendant is a child . The overriding public concern is to protect children . It was not ORG 's intention to punish children unnecessarily or for the criminal law to intervene where it is wholly inappropriate . During the passage of the bill , PERSON said :

' Our overriding concern is to protect children , not to punish them unnecessarily . Where sexual relationships between minors are not abusive , prosecuting either or both children is highly unlikely to be in the public interest . Nor would it be in the best interests of the child .... '

CARDINAL . The Code sets out a number of factors that prosecutors should take into account in deciding whether or not to prosecute , including inter alia the age and understanding of the offender , whether the complainant entered into sexual activity willingly , the relationship between the parties , whether there was any element of exploitation , coercion or threat , deception , grooming or manipulation in the relationship and the nature of the activity . In addition , the best interests and welfare of the complainant and defendant must be taken into account .
